docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: Subdivision 2 Notices of appeal and cross-appeal [rr 51.18–51.23]

heading.title: Subdivision 2 Notices of appeal and cross-appeal [rr 51.18–51.23]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: Subdivision 2 Notices of appeal and cross-appeal [rr 51.18–51.23]
[r 51.18] r 51.18 Contents of notice of appeal (cf SCR Part 51, rule 11)

leg:heading.title: Contents of notice of appeal (cf SCR Part 51, rule 11)

p.text: A notice of appeal must state:
the statutory provision under which the appeal is brought, and
whether it is filed pursuant to leave, and the date leave was given, and
whether the appellant has filed and served a notice of intention to appeal, and the date it was served on the prospective respondent or on the last of the prospective respondents, and
whether the appeal is from the whole or part only, and what part, of the decision below, and
briefly, but specifically, the grounds relied on in support of the appeal, and
what judgment, order, verdict or determination the appellant seeks, and
that, before any attendance before the Court by or on behalf of the respondent, a notice of appearance must be filed if required.
Rule 51.5(2) provides for circumstances in which a respondent need not file a notice of appearance.
Without limiting subrule (1), the appellant must also specify in the notice of appeal any material facts that the appellant contends that the court below should, or should not, have found.
[subr (2) insrt Amendment 21 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[4], effective 7 March 2008]
The approved form for notice of appeal (Court of Appeal) is Form 105.

level.toc-caption: [51.18.5] Grounds of appeal — specific, brief and material

p.text: Legislation cited in [51.18.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 51.18, r 51.18(2), r 51.53.

heading.title: Grounds of appeal — specific, brief and material

p.text: UCPR r 51.18 sets out the requirements of a Notice of Appeal (see also Practice Note SC CA 1 Cl 10). A very significant aspect of these requirements is that the Notice of Appeal should state specifically, but briefly, the grounds of appeal and the material factual findings in contention: Tame v New South Wales (2002) 211 CLR 317; 191 ALR 449; [2002] HCA 35; BC200205111 at [70] per McHugh J (prolixity obscures apparent merit); Penrith Whitewater Stadium Ltd v Lesvos Pty Ltd [2007] NSWCA 103; BC200703149 (14 grounds of appeal all with sub-issues — order to file complying notice).

The Court of Appeal has, on many occasions, stressed the importance of brevity and precision in the formulation of grounds of appeal. Satisfying those requirements demands conscientious assessment and discrimination in identifying the real issues involved in the exercise of the appellate jurisdiction in the particular case.
The notice of appeal should:
succinctly state the basic nature of the challenge to the impugned decision;
identify the respects in which an error in law or fact occurred;
state the nature of any contentious evidence that was the subject or any wrongful admission or rejection of evidence: Pfeiffer v Midland Railway Company (1886) 18 QBD 243 .
The notice of appeal should not:
merely allege that the primary court erred in law or fact;
merely assert that the decision or finding was against the evidence or the weight of evidence: Durham v Durham [2011] NSWCA 62; BC201102298 at [30] per Tobias JA and at [59] per Campbell JA;
descend to a detailed statement of the reasons supporting the grounds of appeal: Sansom v Sansom [1956] 3 All ER 446; [1956] 1 WLR 945 .

In order to achieve the desired precision, an appellant should be familiar with the above prescriptions and with the commonly encountered grounds of appeal and their appropriate use. For a short discussion of some of the grounds of appeal commonly relied upon, reference can usefully be made to [SCA s 75A.15] and UCPR r 51.53 .

The notice should succinctly state the basic nature of the challenge to the impugned decision. The notice of appeal should not descend to a detailed statement of the reasons supporting the grounds of appeal: Sansom v Sansom [1956] 3 All ER 446 .

The grounds of appeal must be more specific than a merely assertive conclusion that the primary court erred in law or fact, or that its decision is against the evidence or the weight of evidence: Durham v Durham [2011] NSWCA 62; BC201102298 at [30] per Tobias JA and at [59] per Campbell JA. The grounds of appeal must identify the respects in which error in law or fact occurred. In addition the grounds should state the findings that the primary court should have made: see UCPR r 51.18(2) and Practice Note SC CA 1 at [10].
If the ground relied upon is the wrongful admission or rejection of evidence, the notice of appeal must state the nature of the evidence in dispute: Pfeiffer v Midland Railway (1886) 18 QBD 243 .

In order to achieve the desired precision, an appellant should be familiar with the prescription authorised above and with the commonly encountered grounds of appeal and their appropriate use. (For a short discussion of some of the grounds of appeal commonly relied upon, reference can usefully be made to [SCA s 75A.15] and UCPR r 51.53 .)
Legislation cited in [51.18.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 51.6–51.9.

Amendment may be sought for many different reasons. Sometimes the urgency of the matter may result in the appeal proceedings being commenced before all relevant information — such as the trial judge’s formal written reasons or the transcript of the proceedings — is available to the appellant. (These exigencies may not be entirely eliminated by the “notice of intention to appeal” provisions in UCPR rr 51.6–51.9 .) In circumstances of these kinds, and indeed whenever amendment of a notice or appeal is appropriate, the present rule authorises the filing of a supplementary notice at any time before the call-over of the appeal: see Chiaverini v Hockey (NSWCA, Kirby P, 13 December 1990, unreported, BC9001619).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.19] r 51.19 How claims for reinstatement or restitution to be made in appeal or cross-appeal

leg:heading.title: How claims for reinstatement or restitution to be made in appeal or cross-appeal

p.text: An appellant or cross-appellant who seeks an order for reinstatement or restitution must include in the notice of appeal or notice of cross-appeal:
a claim for the order and the form of the order, and
where restitution is sought — any claim for interest that is at a rate other than the relevant rate set out in rule 36.7(1) .

As to the practice of the Court in awarding interest where money is ordered to be repaid by way of restitution on the setting aside of a judgment, see Heydon v NRMA Ltd (No 2) (2001) 53 NSWLR 600 at 609 .
[r 51.19 am Amendment 32 of 2010 Sch 1[10] effective 1 July 2010]

This rule requires an appellant (or cross appellant) to specify in the notice of appeal or cross appeal both the form of the order sought, and the interest rate claimed for any restitutionary payment. Unless the notice of appeal specifies a different rate, the judgment interest rate specified in UCPR r 36.7(1) will apply. As to the award of interest on restitutionary payments see [51.54.5] and [51.54.10].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.20] r 51.20 Notice of appeal to specify return day (cf SCR Part 51, rule 42(1))

leg:heading.title: Notice of appeal to specify return day (cf SCR Part 51, rule 42(1))

p.text: A notice of appeal must state a return day.
The return day may be fixed by the Court or obtained from the registry.

If a return day is obtained from the registry and the notice of appeal is to be served outside New South Wales, the return day is to be not less than one month after the date of filing of the notice of appeal.
Rule 10.18 permits the service of documents (including originating process) to be effected in certain circumstances at the address for service provided for the court below.
The approved form for notice of appeal (Court of Appeal) is Form 105.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.21] r 51.21 Alteration of return day in notice of appeal (cf SCR Part 5, rule 5A)

leg:heading.title: Alteration of return day in notice of appeal (cf SCR Part 5, rule 5A)

p.text: The Court may, by notice given to the parties by telephone or otherwise, vary the return day for a notice of appeal to a different day, and may authorise the parties’ solicitors to make corresponding alterations to the copies of the notices of appeal held by them.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.22] r 51.22 Absence of restrictions on appeals as of right to be shown by affidavit (cf SCR Part 51, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Absence of restrictions on appeals as of right to be shown by affidavit (cf SCR Part 51, rule 8)

p.text: This rule applies if an appeal or cross-appeal as of right is restricted by any Act by reference to:
a specified amount or value, or
any other specified circumstance or matter (such as a restriction based on questions of law).
The appellant or cross-appellant must, on filing the notice of appeal or cross-appeal, file and serve on each necessary party an affidavit that:
identifies the nature of the restriction (including a reference to the provision of the Act that imposes the restriction), and
sets out the material facts on which the appellant or cross-appellant relies to show that the restriction does not apply.

level.toc-caption: [51.22.5] Statutory restrictions on the right of appeal

p.text: Legislation cited in [51.22.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 75A.

heading.title: Statutory restrictions on the right of appeal

p.text: There are various statutory restrictions on rights of appeal. These restrictions may operate by reference to different criteria but the most commonly encountered restrictions relate to the nature of the particular decision (eg, whether it is a final, interlocutory, consent or costs decision) and the amount in issue in the proposed appeal (see generally SCA ss 101(2)(r) and 75A and s 127(2) of the District Court Act 1973).

The mere fact that an appeal document is accepted for filing in the court registry does not in any way substantiate the existence of a right of appeal. The Registry has no function to assess the competency of a filed appeal. On the contrary, the basic purpose of UCPR r 51.22 is to impose on prospective appellants the onus of demonstrating the competence of their appeal: Boulos v Martin (No 3) [2012] NSWCA 162 at [9]–[10], [12], [15] .

level.toc-caption: [51.22.6] Affidavit evidence substantiating right of appeal

heading.title: Affidavit evidence substantiating right of appeal

p.text: Where there is a relevant threshold restriction on the right of appeal, an appellant must demonstrate compliance with the restriction — by providing the affidavit evidence required under the present rule. The affidavit must disclose the factual circumstances demonstrating why the appeal lies as of right. It is not sufficient for an appellant merely to assert belief in compliance with the rule: Anthony v Maglovenos (NSWCA, 11 July 1978, unreported); followed in Ozpinar v Assaily [2001] NSWCA 23; BC200100359 ; Kassem v Colonial Mutual General Insurance Co Ltd [2001] NSWCA 38; BC200100671 at [47], [57] and [62] . Nor is it sufficient to assert either belief as to the amount involved: Trad v Harbour Radio Pty Ltd [2010] NSWCA 41; BC201001404 at [6]–[9] ; or reliance on instructions or advice: Maynes v Casey [2011] NSWCA 156; BC201104480 at [4] and [10] . The affidavit must outline the facts (including relevant findings in the reasons for judgment) from which the probable value of the amount involved can be assessed in a reasonably informed way. It is not appropriate to seek to demonstrate the amount involved by reference to material that was not in evidence before the trial judge, and which has no prospect of being admitted as fresh or further evidence on the appeal: Schepis v Commonwealth [2012] NSWCA 398; BC201210641 at [27] per Campbell JA. If the appellant’s affidavit does not demonstrate compliance with the threshold requirement, the respondent may apply to strike out the purported appeal as incompetent. If the appellant’s affidavit does not demonstrate compliance with the threshold requirement, the respondent may apply to strike out the purported appeal as incompetent.
Legislation cited in [51.22.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Administrative Decisions Tribunal Act 1997 s 119.
(NSW) Legal Profession Act 2004 s 729A.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 142N, ss 127.
(NSW) Government and Related Employees Appeal Tribunal Act 1980 s 54.
(NSW) Land and Environment Court Act 1979 ss 57, 58.
(NSW) Workplace Injury Management and Workers Compensation Act 1998 s 353.
The main provisions relating to rights of appeal to the Court of Appeal (including rights contingent on leave) are as follows.
Supreme Court:
SCA s 101 (general provision, including matters requiring leave).
SCA s 101A (question of law concerning criminal contempt).
SCA s 102 (appeal after Supreme Court jury trial).
SCA s 103 (appeal from separate decision in Supreme Court).
Administrative Decisions Tribunal:
Administrative Decisions Tribunal Act 1997 s 119 (appeal on a question of law; interlocutory, consent and costs decisions require leave).
Legal Profession Act 2004 s 729A (appeal from ADT decision to Supreme Court).
SCA s 48(1)(a)(vii) (where the ADT Appeal Panel includes a judge of the District Court: Daykin v SAS Trustee Corp (2001) 51 NSWLR 328; [2001] NSWSC 58; BC200100561 ).
SCA s 48(1)(a)(viii) (Appeal Panel or Legal Services Division of ADT is a “specified tribunal”).
District Court:

DCA ss 127 (interlocutory , costs, summary judgment, consent decisions and small judgments require leave), 142N (appeal on point of law or a question about evidence in residual jurisdiction; interlocutory, costs and consent decisions require leave).
SCA s 48(1)(a)(iv) (District Court is a “specified tribunal”).
Dust Diseases Tribunal:
Dust Diseases Tribunal Act 1989: s 32 (appeal on point of law or a question about of evidence; interlocutory, costs and consent decisions require leave).
SCA s 48(1)(a)(iia) (DDT is a “specified tribunal”).
GREAT:
Government and Related Employees Appeal Tribunal Act 1980 s 54 (appeal on point of law).
SCA s 48(1)(a)(iii) (GREAT is a “specified tribunal”).
Land and Environment Court:
Land and Environment Court Act 1979 ss 57 , 58 (appeal on a question of law; interlocutory, costs and consent decisions require leave).
SCA s 48(1)(a)(i) (LEC is a “specified tribunal”).
Other tribunals:

If the relevant statute confers a right of appeal on the Supreme Court and if SCA s 48(1)(a)(vii) (a body having amongst its number a judge) applies, then the appeal is assigned to the Court of Appeal: Daykin v SAS Trustee Corp (2001) 51 NSWLR 328; [2001] NSWSC 58; BC200100561 .
Workers Compensation Commission constituted by Presidential Member:
Workplace Injury Management and Workers Compensation Act 1998 s 353 (appeal as to point of law; interlocutory, costs and consent decisions require leave).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.23] r 51.23 Amendment of notice of appeal (cf SCR Part 51, rule 17)

leg:heading.title: Amendment of notice of appeal (cf SCR Part 51, rule 17)

p.text: Part 19 (Amendment) applies to the amendment of a notice of appeal in the same way it applies to the amendment of a statement of claim.

For example, rule 19.1 provides that a plaintiff may, without leave, amend a statement of claim once within 28 days after the date on which it was filed, but, unless the court otherwise orders, may not amend it after a date has been fixed for trial.
